text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane. Locus is the trade newspaper in the science fiction field. 1983 marked the 16th year of publication and Locus has won seven Hugo Awards. The founder of Locus is Charles Brown, whom we talked with recently. Here Brown tells us how and why he started Locus and how it has evolved. Well I started Locus in 1968. It started, one of the main reasons I started was I wanted to be able to learn how to write. I was a full-time fan, I could never seem to write anybody a letter. So I decided if I had myself a deadline at that time, it was over two weeks, I would get some experience with writing, I'll be able to write letters and things like that. Well it's fifteen years later, I still can't write letters, I'll just put out some magazines. It mainly evolved from being about fandom. It was done on every other weekend, it was written on Friday, stencils on Saturday, runoff and mail on Sunday. It was always every other weekend with a gang of people in the house helping out and things like that. It just kept growing. The one thing about our magazine is if you keep putting out issues you get more and more news. Gradually it changed over, more towards the professional side. Mainly because that's where my interests were. They were the people who responded more often than I was. Eventually it grew to a point where I couldn't print it anymore. We went to professional printing and it's been growing ever since. It's about the late of a short novel now, started out as just one page. So that's how it grew. Locus has grown to be a major force in the science fiction field. We asked Brown if in the early days he ever anticipated that Locus would get to be so important. Well no, it originally started out to only run for two years. One of the other things that started out was that this was a advertisement for the Boston group who was bidding for a world time. I just wrote the original and the Boston group put it out but that didn't work very well. At the end of two years they did win the convention, I think mainly because of Locus. But then we discovered that we were being nominated for a year ago. It seemed like it would be interesting to run it right through the Boston convention and try and win a year ago. Which we did and after that we just never stopped. But I never imagined it would grow that much. Brown worked for many years as an electrical engineer and produced Locus part time. Then that changed. There was a break in the engineering field in 1975. I got laid off for the first time in my life. I figured while I was waiting for the field to pick up again, I would try writing for the year. So I did. I wrote mostly nonfiction articles from magazines. I did Locus on the side and tried to build it up as much as possible. And eventually I discovered I didn't even have to go back to work. Every once in a while I get a call for an engineering job. I feel very good about that but I have no intention of doing that. One question that naturally springs to mind is, what is the origin of Locus? The name came from various points. Various things. Locus is the connecting point in a circle. We considered ourselves the connecting point for the science fiction professionals, fans and publishers. The other thing was just from the old Spanish phrase of L.R.C. The letter of comment. That's why the letter column is still called Locus for the capital of L.R.C. Join us on our next show when we'll talk more with Charles Brown. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show Next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And Bill Vernon. Locus is Science Fiction's leading trade magazine. It's written for professional writers and for serious readers. The professionals get information on prospective markets. The readers get up-to-date information on reviews, conventions and forthcoming books. But Locus has its roots in fandom. Charles Brown, its founder, editor and publisher, tells us how he discovered science fiction fandom soon after he began reading science fiction. Oh, I started reading science fiction. I was reading a founding in the 40s. And I started fandom all around 1949. By finding conventions listed in one of the magazines, Super Science Story, or something like that. I was to the 1950s convention. I was 12 years old when I went to this convention. I had a wonderful time. And I met all these old men, like Fred Cole and Bester Del Rey. They were old. Most of them were pushing 30. When you're 12, you don't think anybody's ever going to reach 30. It's really up there. And now it's frightening because I met two other people and they're considered the same age pretty much. But double-sword, silver fandom. And I put out my first fan scene about 1951. Dropped out again when I was in college. And things like that. And then she went back to the late 50s. So Brown has been involved in fandom since 1950. We asked him how fandom has changed through the years. 1950, there were all these 13-year-old kids and I was right there. I was talking to Harlan Ellison today. He said the one thing he just came back from Australia, he was just a monarchy, an Australian convention. It's just like the American fandom of the 50s. There were all these 13-year-old kids and no women. They were all very sincere, very bright, and very socially inept. It's a pretty well-fandomed and most nice kid. Annually Brown conducts the Locust Poll. The Poll is a tally of readers' responses to such topics as favorite novels, short stories, artists, and so on. And it reveals some personal information as well. One bit of information is that the average Locust reader seems to be getting older. Our audience is always going to gotten older. Mainly because the audience has stayed with us. About 80% of the people who read Locust in 1968 still read Locust. Which of course keeps raising the ages. There are some new people, but not that many. What are the changes of course in the magazine? The magazine is no longer aimed at a teenage fan. It's aimed at professionals. Of course it means we attract the older professionals. I think there are probably no more than two or three professionals who are not the providers. Brown has been publishing Locust for 16 years. We ask him if he still gets satisfaction from it. I was looking at the Blue Lines for the new issue today. It was very exciting. The first time you see it come together. You see all the photographs together. All the stories in one place. The pieces. You still got a real thrill when you hold that first copy. I'll get my final copy tomorrow. I'll be down at the printer 8.30 in the morning watching it run off. I'll pull out a copy myself and stay put together. And then I'll have another copy. We'll have more with Charles Brown on our next show. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show. A production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show. So stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show. A commentary on science fiction and fantasy. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane. Pick up a copy of Locust, Science Fiction's leading trade newspaper. Look inside the front page and you'll find a small box entitled Editorial Matters. In the editorial you'll find, among other acknowledgments, the names of people who helped collate, fold, and mail the copies of the issue. We asked Charles Brown, the founder, editor, and publisher of Locust, to describe how a typical Locust issue is put together prior to mailing. People come over to mail them. Well, it's not collated. It's mailing books. We get the picture back from the printer in the afternoon and one or two people may show up and help us put stamps on first-class copies. Then a larger crowd comes in the evening. You see over there's said dinner and sit around and drink and put out... We put all the labels on the thing and put it outside the order. And the chronological order by zip code. And there's fact-dots in. Usually we finish by about 10.30 or 11. Everybody sits around and talks about Science Fiction. Very few of the people are of what you call science. There almost all writers. In fact, we had a contest last year. It's the best first novel by a Locust co-lager. We did have three nominees. As far as I can tell, probably about 90% of the Locusts are collated with at least one novel. Locust has grown from a small fanzine to a professionally produced, nearly 50-page-long publication. We asked Brown if he plans to continue expanding Locusts. His answer may surprise you. Actually, I'd like to do the opposite. I do not want to expand the magazine at all. It will expand anyway. It always does. But I have no interest in doing a bigger magazine. In fact, I find a magazine too big now and the situation too bad. I really want to do a magazine for a limited number of people. Where I can do it all myself at home. I'm very frightened about getting to the point where I need a larger staff and an office. Everything is going at home right now. Some of the changes are always forced on us because there's more news that we feel we have to cover. As you probably noticed, we're doing a lot more international coverage lately. Covering the Soviet Union and the European Convention. And we've had articles on Chinese science. And I'm off to China next week to an other U.S. university, Shanghai, and South Korea, between there. Locust has caught seven Hugo awards so far. Is brown tiring and winning so many Hugo's? I don't get tired of winning them now. It's a lot of fun. There have been complaints but they don't bother me too much. I solved the problem with complaints. I sent Rachel out to pick them up every year. I won't stand for you as long as people vote for Locust, I'll gladly accept Hugo. Locust is a visible presence in the science fiction field. We asked Brown if it is a target for writers of crackpot letters. I tell you, I eat crackpot letters all the time. Really strange letters and we usually throw them out. The years we've collected all these really strange, far outlaid letters, ways waiting to publish them in a final issue. But it doesn't look like there will be a final issue with Locust. So there's no reason to keep them around anymore. If you're a serious science fiction fan, you need to be reading Locust. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The Science Fiction Radio Show Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us. This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Daryl Lane. And Bill Vernon. The late H.B.Piper created in his fiction a race of small, furry, sentient creatures called fuzzies. These cute aliens proved to be very popular with the fans. Fuzzy's figured in only two books, Little Fuzzy, and what was later called Fuzzy Sapiens, before Piper died. But according to Ardeth Mayhar, who recently wrote another installment in the Fuzzy saga entitled Golden Dream of Fuzzy Odyssey, the fuzzy series did not stop with Piper's death. Well, Mr. Piper died in 1966. A suicide, which was a very tragic thing. And he left a considerable literary estate. He had been writing rather successfully for a long time. There was sort of a hiatus there for a number of years until one of his friends, I believe it was Jerry Purnell, but I'm not certain, persuaded A's to purchase his literary estate. All the rights and all of his books and short stories and everything, which they did. And they reissued Little Fuzzy and Fuzzy Sapiens in a single volume under the fuzzy papers. And it was very successful. Had a built-in market of people who remembered the books. And so they decided that they wanted another book. So they turned to Mr. William Tuning, who wrote a third book, Fuzzy Bones, which I enjoyed very much. I based a great deal of the background of my book on the substructure that he had created for their historical background. After Tuning's effort, May Hart told us, she was asked to write a fuzzy novel. Here she tells us why. I believe it was Susan Allison, who was then the head science fiction editor at A's, decided that they wanted a book from the viewpoint of the little aliens. Well, my editor had just bought paperback rights to my first two double-day books. And she was in the process of putting them into production for A's. And she had had a great deal of back and forth conversation with my agent, who is still black staggered at how fast I am. And so one day the phone rang, that dear phone, it was Susan Allison. She said, would you be interested in writing a book to continue H. Bean Piper's fuzzy series? Are you familiar with mine? I said, yes, I've got my teeth on them. And she said, well, would you be interested? We want one from the viewpoint of the aliens. And she said, I shouldn't say this, but we were kicking it around the office and trying to figure who was extremely fast and partly alien. And naturally we thought of you. Well, I was flat, you know, because I am both. So I said, well, I'll tell you what, I will reread the books. And then I will write whatever feels comfortable so that I know how well I fit into a fuzzy skin. And you will be able to tell how well you like what I do. And then we'll go from there. To write about fuzzies, may her found it necessary to put herself in their place. This was in early February. So I sat down and it's a very funny thing. Becoming an alien is not all that difficult, but you have to have been a very peculiar child. You'll be able to do it well. So I remembered when I was two feet tall. I can remember back before I was two years old. I remembered how the world is full of shoes and kneecaps. You know, everything is tremendous. Shrubs or trees and trees are just something up there like clouds, you know. So I shrunk myself down to two feet tall and put myself on a world where everything thought I was delicious. And went from there. On our next show, we'll hear more from Ardith Mayhar on her writing of Golden Dream of Fuzzy Odyssey. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association, produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas. The next show is the Science Fiction Radio Show. Stay with us! This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy. And here are your hosts. This is Bill Vernon. And Daryl Lane. H. Bean Piper's Fuzzy series was only two books long when he died. William Tuning wrote a third novel in this series called Fuzzy Bones. Then Ace Books asked Ardith Mayhar to write a fourth novel. Her continuation of the series, which came out in 1982, was called Golden Dream of Fuzzy Odyssey, and it's told from the viewpoint of the fuzzies. As we've learned in our last show, Mayhar used childhood memories to put herself mentally in the place of the two-foot-tall fuzzies. Mayhar's treatment of the fuzzies diverges quite a bit from the treatments given them by Piper and Tuning, though. The treatment of the fuzzies in both Piper and Tuning books is rather peripheral to the human story, and the fuzzies are given rather short shrift as sort of cutesy poo creatures. Okay, Mr. Tuning had set up that they had survived on this totally inimical planet for 1,200 years. So little helpless big-eyed cutesy poos don't survive for 1,200 years. You've got to have pretty bright, gritty little cats, or they're not going to make it. Mayhar also took the approach of answering some of the mysteries at which Piper and Tuning had only hinted. Well, I had some awfully neat questions to answer that had been set up in the other books and had never been addressed in those books. Why did they speak in ultrasonics? Why being obviously rational creatures capable of great affection were they sexually promiscuous? Oh, there were any number of questions that I had to answer. It was so funny because as I went, I just turned, okay, this is what they are, and I turned around and looked, and this was obviously the reason they were that way. They were sexually promiscuous, for instance, because when their spaceship crashed, a complement of only some 400 were aboard. And some half of those were subsequently killed in an earthquake. So you had a gene pool shared among something around 150 or 200 individuals. You had to spread your genetic heritage around. And so this would be a natural outgrowth of assigned breeding as long as they were in the original valley. And then when they went out, they retained this imperative from their leaders, you must do this for racial survival. There were any number of things like that. One of the reasons Mayhar was asked to write a fuzzy novel was that she can write at such a rapid pace. Ace needed the book as soon as they could get their hands on it. Here Mayhar comments on the production of Golden Dream, a fuzzy odyssey. Anyhow, they loved what I did. I loved what I did. I wrote that book, 100,000 words in six weeks. I sat on a wicker stool, which is now permanently imprinted on my derriere. My husband would come in, he would have left me sitting on the stool that morning. He'd come in that evening and say, you haven't eaten, have you? I'd say, eaten? What's eaten? But it was a lot of fun. Both the trade edition and the mass market edition of Golden Dream, a fuzzy odyssey, feature the same stunning Michael Whalen cover. We asked Mayhar if she had any input. No, but I knew it was going to be beautiful because Mike Whalen had done the covers for the Piper books and for the tuning book. And so I knew what he could do. We wondered if Mayhar would be willing to write another fuzzy novel. I just wouldn't mind at all writing another one. They're nice little people. They really are. On some of our future shows, we'll talk more with Ardith Mayhar about her other fiction. This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, a production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas.

segments.text: Coming up next is the Science Fiction Radio Show, so stay with us.
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Bill Vernon and Daryl Lane.
Locus is the trade newspaper in the science fiction field.
1983 marked the 16th year of publication and Locus has won seven Hugo Awards.
The founder of Locus is Charles Brown, whom we talked with recently.
Here Brown tells us how and why he started Locus and how it has evolved.
Well I started Locus in 1968.
It started, one of the main reasons I started was I wanted to be able to learn how to write.
I was a full-time fan, I could never seem to write anybody a letter.
So I decided if I had myself a deadline at that time, it was over two weeks,
I would get some experience with writing, I'll be able to write letters and things like that.
Well it's fifteen years later, I still can't write letters, I'll just put out some magazines.
It mainly evolved from being about fandom.
It was done on every other weekend, it was written on Friday,
stencils on Saturday, runoff and mail on Sunday.
It was always every other weekend with a gang of people in the house helping out and things like that.
It just kept growing.
The one thing about our magazine is if you keep putting out issues you get more and more news.
Gradually it changed over, more towards the professional side.
Mainly because that's where my interests were.
They were the people who responded more often than I was.
Eventually it grew to a point where I couldn't print it anymore.
We went to professional printing and it's been growing ever since.
It's about the late of a short novel now, started out as just one page.
So that's how it grew.
Locus has grown to be a major force in the science fiction field.
We asked Brown if in the early days he ever anticipated that Locus would get to be so important.
Well no, it originally started out to only run for two years.
One of the other things that started out was that this was a advertisement for the Boston group who was bidding for a world time.
I just wrote the original and the Boston group put it out but that didn't work very well.
At the end of two years they did win the convention, I think mainly because of Locus.
But then we discovered that we were being nominated for a year ago.
It seemed like it would be interesting to run it right through the Boston convention and try and win a year ago.
Which we did and after that we just never stopped.
But I never imagined it would grow that much.
Brown worked for many years as an electrical engineer and produced Locus part time.
Then that changed.
There was a break in the engineering field in 1975.
I got laid off for the first time in my life.
I figured while I was waiting for the field to pick up again, I would try writing for the year.
So I did. I wrote mostly nonfiction articles from magazines.
I did Locus on the side and tried to build it up as much as possible.
And eventually I discovered I didn't even have to go back to work.
Every once in a while I get a call for an engineering job.
I feel very good about that but I have no intention of doing that.
One question that naturally springs to mind is, what is the origin of Locus?
The name came from various points.
Various things.
Locus is the connecting point in a circle.
We considered ourselves the connecting point for the science fiction professionals, fans and publishers.
The other thing was just from the old Spanish phrase of L.R.C.
The letter of comment.
That's why the letter column is still called Locus for the capital of L.R.C.
Join us on our next show when we'll talk more with Charles Brown.
This has been the Science Fiction Radio Show, production of the Permian Basin Science Fiction Association,
produced in conjunction with Odessa College in Odessa, Texas.

The pieces.

I'll get my final copy tomorrow.

I'll pull out a copy myself and stay put together.

Shanghai, and South Korea, between there.

I don't get tired of winning them now. It's a lot of fun.

So I remembered when I was two feet tall.
I can remember back before I was two years old.
I remembered how the world is full of shoes and kneecaps.
You know, everything is tremendous.
Shrubs or trees and trees are just something up there like clouds, you know.
So I shrunk myself down to two feet tall and put myself on a world where everything thought I was delicious.
And went from there.
On our next show, we'll hear more from Ardith Mayhar on her writing of Golden Dream of Fuzzy Odyssey.

The next show is the Science Fiction Radio Show.
Stay with us!
This is the Science Fiction Radio Show, a commentary on science fiction and fantasy.
And here are your hosts.
This is Bill Vernon.
And Daryl Lane.
H. Bean Piper's Fuzzy series was only two books long when he died.
William Tuning wrote a third novel in this series called Fuzzy Bones.
Then Ace Books asked Ardith Mayhar to write a fourth novel.
Her continuation of the series, which came out in 1982, was called Golden Dream of Fuzzy Odyssey,
and it's told from the viewpoint of the fuzzies.
As we've learned in our last show, Mayhar used childhood memories to put herself mentally in the place of the two-foot-tall fuzzies.
Mayhar's treatment of the fuzzies diverges quite a bit from the treatments given them by Piper and Tuning, though.
The treatment of the fuzzies in both Piper and Tuning books is rather peripheral to the human story,
and the fuzzies are given rather short shrift as sort of cutesy poo creatures.
Okay, Mr. Tuning had set up that they had survived on this totally inimical planet for 1,200 years.
So little helpless big-eyed cutesy poos don't survive for 1,200 years.
You've got to have pretty bright, gritty little cats, or they're not going to make it.
Mayhar also took the approach of answering some of the mysteries at which Piper and Tuning had only hinted.
Well, I had some awfully neat questions to answer that had been set up in the other books and had never been addressed in those books.
Why did they speak in ultrasonics?
Why being obviously rational creatures capable of great affection were they sexually promiscuous?
Oh, there were any number of questions that I had to answer.
It was so funny because as I went, I just turned, okay, this is what they are, and I turned around and looked,
and this was obviously the reason they were that way.
They were sexually promiscuous, for instance, because when their spaceship crashed,
a complement of only some 400 were aboard.
And some half of those were subsequently killed in an earthquake.
So you had a gene pool shared among something around 150 or 200 individuals.
You had to spread your genetic heritage around.
And so this would be a natural outgrowth of assigned breeding as long as they were in the original valley.
And then when they went out, they retained this imperative from their leaders,
you must do this for racial survival.
There were any number of things like that.
One of the reasons Mayhar was asked to write a fuzzy novel was that she can write at such a rapid pace.
Ace needed the book as soon as they could get their hands on it.
Here Mayhar comments on the production of Golden Dream, a fuzzy odyssey.
Anyhow, they loved what I did.
I loved what I did.
I wrote that book, 100,000 words in six weeks.
I sat on a wicker stool, which is now permanently imprinted on my derriere.
My husband would come in, he would have left me sitting on the stool that morning.
He'd come in that evening and say, you haven't eaten, have you?
I'd say, eaten? What's eaten?
But it was a lot of fun.
Both the trade edition and the mass market edition of Golden Dream, a fuzzy odyssey,
feature the same stunning Michael Whalen cover.
We asked Mayhar if she had any input.
No, but I knew it was going to be beautiful because Mike Whalen had done the covers for the Piper books and for the tuning book.
And so I knew what he could do.
We wondered if Mayhar would be willing to write another fuzzy novel.
I just wouldn't mind at all writing another one.
They're nice little people. They really are.
On some of our future shows, we'll talk more with Ardith Mayhar about her other fiction.
